awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity in STEM Education Research via the POGIL Community
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to promote discipline-based education research (DBER) within the Process-oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL) community of practitioners.  Specifically, the project team will host a workshop for early- and mid-career POGIL practitioners led by a team of five DBER scholars. The goal of this event is to introduce current POGIL practitioners to the knowledge and skills involved in design, implementation, and methodology of STEM education research. The participants will be placed into teams of four based on their research interests.  Over the following year, the teams will be supported to develop and implement a DBER project related to the POGIL approach.  This support will include regular virtual meetings where one of the DBER scholars will serve as mentor. A final follow-up meeting will be held at the end of the year to assess progress and plan for future work. The participants’ extensive experience with students and POGIL learning environments will provide a rich base of practice from which to develop and investigate meaningful research questions. 

This project has the potential to be transformative for the sixteen veteran POGIL practitioners who will participate, positioning them to be new contributors of high-quality STEM education research. The results of their research will provide new evidence about the impact of the POGIL pedagogy on student outcomes, learning of diverse and at-risk student populations, and instructors’ teaching skills. The project is designed to develop a large research team that can explore POGIL pedagogy in multifaceted ways, thus addressing a challenge posed in the NRC’s 2012 Discipline-Based Education Research report. This project will also examine the impact of each component of the conference model, including involvement of people with existing community membership, conference session content and process, continued mentoring, and team structure. This project may help integrate the large POGIL community of practitioners more strongly with the DBER research community, thus enhancing the opportunities for research to inform STEM pedagogy and for STEM pedagogy to inform research.  This project is supported by the ECR: Building Capacity in STEM Education Research competition of the EHR Core Research (ECR) program. ECR funds STEM education research projects that are focused on STEM learning and learning environment, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM professional workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to introduce current POGIL practitioners at the post-secondary level to the knowledge and skills involved in design, implementation, and analysis of STEM education investigations. Participants included early- and mid-career faculty who are experienced practitioners and innovators of POGIL’s research-based pedagogy and who have a desire to advance understanding of how student-centered pedagogies such as POGIL improve student outcomes. Fifteen participants experienced a combination of virtual and face-to-face professional development experiences led by an expert facilitation team of discipline-based education research scholars. The participants were placed into four teams who worked collaboratively to design and implement research projects of their own choosing, with mentoring and consultation provided by the facilitation team.

All four teams successfully executed their research projects during the 2022-23 academic year and presented their results at a poster session at the National Conference to Advance POGIL Practice in June 2023 at the University of Utah. The topics and key findings from each of these projects were:

  1. Developing a Sense of Belonging in POGIL Gateway Classes: Although no significant gains in sense of belonging were seen throughout the single semester of this study, the extent of science belonging at the end of the course was strongly correlated with enrollment in the next course in the sequence.
  2. Promoting Teamwork in the Classroom: The intentional inclusion of neither written nor oral prompts concerning teamwork were effective in eliciting significant change in teamwork behavior. However, the use of a written rubric specifically designed to provide feedback on teamwork behavior did result in statistically significant positive change in teamwork behavior.
  3. Examination of Effort Belief and Self-Competence in Classrooms using Mastery-Based Grading and Active Learning:  Results show that, for students in first-semester general chemistry at a small, primarily undergraduate, private institution in the U.S. Midwest, the initial effort-belief scores were high and remained high at the end of the course. However, students with low initial self-competency scores improved significantly (p=0.01) in the Mastery-Based Grading/active- learning course, but not in the passive learning, conventional grading course.
  4. Impact of Teaching Evidence-Based Learning Strategies: After explicit instruction about evidence-based effective learning strategies, some students reported changes in their study habits in preparation for exams. However, there was no clear evidence of an increase in self-efficacy as a result of the intervention.

All four teams are continuing their research in the 2023-24 academic year following completion of the project, and virtually all participants plan on incorporating discipline-based education research in their ongoing scholarly work. This pilot project has demonstrated an effective approach for supporting post-secondary faculty who are interested in transitioning their scholarship into discipline-based education research.
